data.title: Celsius targets gross margin return to low 50% by end of 2026 as integration and innovation drive portfolio expansion
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Celsius Holdings, Inc. (CELH) Q4 2025

Management View

  • John Fieldly, CEO, opened by highlighting that "We continue to execute with momentum and operating discipline, and we are reinforcing the scale of our platform as we build a modern energy portfolio." He announced a full year record revenue of $2.5 billion and emphasized the disciplined approach to growth and scale, with a focus on consumer proximity and execution alongside Pepsi and retail partners.
  • Fieldly stated the portfolio, including CELSIUS, Alani Nu, and Rockstar Energy, now represents approximately 1/5 of the U.S. energy market in tracked channels for the full year, and contains two billion-dollar brands. He outlined strategic efforts to broaden reach, stating integration of Alani Nu into the PepsiCo system is substantially complete, with full completion expected by the end of Q1 2026, and Rockstar integration targeted for the first half of 2026.
  • Fieldly highlighted innovation such as the national launch of the Fizz-Free line and a more intentional cadence of limited time offers (LTOs) to expand reach and trial. International expansion is a long-term growth lever, now present in about 10 markets, with a new President of International, Garrett Quigley, brought on to scale global operations.
  • On marketing, Fieldly introduced a new in-house brand studio to unify and accelerate brand storytelling and activation across the portfolio. He reiterated the focus on zero sugar, functional energy, and operational discipline to maintain relevance and drive sustainable growth.
  • Jarrod Langhans, CFO, provided context on the accounting treatment for Rockstar during integration, with $45 million recorded in net sales and an additional $6 million in other income for the quarter. "As we move into the first quarter, we expect to fully transition the U.S. portion of the business to the finished goods model and we expect that only the Canadian portion will remain in the other income."

Outlook

  • Fieldly stated, "We have a clear strategy and priorities for 2026 and believe they will support sustainable, profitable growth." Langhans indicated that as integrations progress, "we expect margins to expand across 2026 and return to a more normalized profile, with gross margins in the low 50s driven by savings across raw materials, scrap, manufacturing tolling fees, freight and package and brand mix, offset in part by tariffs and aluminum costs."
  • Management expects the Alani integration to be completed by the end of Q1 2026 and Rockstar by the first half of 2026, projecting that integration and operational efficiencies will support margin expansion.

Financial Results

  • Consolidated Q4 revenue was approximately $722 million, with full year consolidated revenue at $2.5 billion. Alani Nu achieved record net sales of $370 million in Q4, contributing $1 billion since acquisition. Brand CELSIUS delivered $1.46 billion in net sales for the year, growing 7.5% year-over-year.
  • Gross profit for Q4 was $341.8 million, with a margin of 47.4%, impacted by dilution from Rockstar and integration costs. Full year gross profit margin was 50.4%.
  • GAAP net income for the quarter was $24.7 million and adjusted EBITDA was $134.1 million. Operating cash flow was $359 million for the year, with $399 million in cash and $670 million in total debt at year end. The company reduced debt by $200 million and repurchased $40 million in shares during Q4, with $260 million remaining under the repurchase program.

Q&A

  • Filippo Falorni, Citigroup, asked about spring shelf space resets and the timing of benefits. CEO Fieldly responded, "We do expect those to continue to materialize through the end of spring, really with the biggest gains, especially for Alani, would be in convenience."
  • Peter Grom, UBS, inquired about the $25 million net benefit from CELSIUS vs. Alani and inventory levels. CFO Langhans said, "We're committed to really tightening up those peaks and valleys...as a portfolio, playing a much more scaled business, we'll be able to get those a bit tighter and manage that."
  • Bonnie Herzog, Goldman Sachs, questioned gross margin trajectory and Midwest premium impact. Langhans replied, "Our target for this year is to get back to a more normalized low 50s...Alani will be fully integrated by end of Q1 and Rockstar by the end of Q2."
  • Andrea Teixeira, JPMorgan, addressed SKU prioritization and margin predictability. Fieldly emphasized, "Velocity is very important in the category. That's what is going to continue to drive it."
  • Kevin Grundy, BNP Paribas, focused on distribution gains, shelf space sources, and velocity. Fieldly noted, "There is a lot more space coming in the energy category as it's becoming part of a daily lifestyle, daily routine."
  • Gerald Pascarelli, Needham, asked about inventory benefits and shelf space growth for Alani. Langhans explained, "I would definitely see that as more of an opportunistic move as opposed to a pull back or pull forward." Fieldly described Alani's expansion as driven by category growth and evolving consumer dynamics.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts' tone was inquisitive and slightly pressing, focused on inventory timing, margin recovery, and the sustainability of velocity and shelf space gains.
  • Management delivered confident, disciplined responses, frequently referencing operational rigor and tight alignment with retail partners. Fieldly stated, "We feel confident with the innovation. We're going to see the space gains."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone remained optimistic but provided more detail on integration milestones and operational discipline, while analysts pressed for greater clarity on timing and risk factors.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • This quarter saw explicit updates on integration progress and margin recovery plans, compared to last quarter’s focus on the initial impact of acquisitions and distribution expansion.
  • Management shifted from discussing the mechanics of integration to providing concrete timelines and targets, such as gross margin returning to the low 50% range by the end of 2026.
  • Analysts continued to probe inventory movements and margin sustainability, but questions became more focused on the operational cadence and risk of volatility as integrations near completion.
  • Key metrics such as consolidated revenue, gross margins, and inventory-related timing effects were expanded upon in detail this quarter relative to Q3.

Risks and Concerns

  • Integration and distribution transition costs impacted gross margin, with ongoing volatility possible as integrations complete.
  • Management cited tariffs and aluminum costs as ongoing headwinds, while emphasizing mitigation through operational efficiencies and scale.
  • Analysts consistently raised concerns about volatility in inventory management, timing of shelf resets, and the pace of margin normalization.

Final Takeaway

Celsius Holdings management underscored that 2025 was a year of record revenue and major portfolio scale as the company integrated Alani Nu and Rockstar, with the focus now on completing integrations, expanding shelf space, and driving operational discipline. The company projects gross margin to return to the low 50% range by the end of 2026, supported by integration synergies, supply chain improvements, and ongoing innovation, while continuing to prioritize brand growth and long-term value creation.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Climb Global Solutions targets $250M in Fortinet gross billings within 18 months as M&A strategy accelerates
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Climb Global Solutions (CLMB) Q4 2025

Management View

  • CEO Dale Foster described 2025 as "another exceptional year for Climb as we generated record results across all key financial metrics." Foster highlighted the company's selective vendor onboarding, stating, "In the fourth quarter alone, we evaluated nearly 100 potential vendor relationships and signed agreements with only 2 of them."
  • Foster announced a new partnership with Fortinet, calling it "quickly becoming a primary onboarding focus" and expected to become a "meaningful contributor" to the business. He also detailed the ongoing relationship with Darktrace, noting, "In Q4, Climb had 70 partners transact over $13 million in Darktrace product offerings."
  • Foster revealed the acquisition of interworks.cloud, a Greece-based specialist cloud distributor, stating it "enhance[s] our ability to drive cross-sell opportunities, deepen our engagement with our vendors and reseller partners and further position Climb as a distributor of choice across the Southeastern Europe region."
  • Foster explained the strategic rationale: "We expect the transaction to be immediately accretive to our earnings and adjusted EBITDA and look forward to unlocking synergies and cross-selling opportunities."
  • CFO Matthew Sullivan reported, "Gross billings increased 3% to $625.4 million compared to $605 million in the year ago quarter... Net sales in the fourth quarter of 2025 increased 20% to $193.8 million compared to $161.8 million, which primarily reflects organic growth from new and existing vendors." He added, "Net income in the fourth quarter of 2025 remained flat at $7 million or $1.52 per diluted share compared to the prior year period."
  • Sullivan announced, "The Board has determined to suspend our quarterly cash dividend beginning in the first quarter of 2026. This decision allows us to retain additional capital to support organic growth initiatives and strategic acquisitions while further strengthening our financial flexibility."

Outlook

  • Foster emphasized, "Looking ahead, we remain focused on accelerating organic growth... We will also continue to pursue accretive M&A opportunities that can strengthen our vendor portfolio and expand our geographic footprint."
  • Sullivan stated, "With a disciplined approach to expansion and a continued focus on execution, we believe we are well positioned to deliver another year of growth and enhance profitability in 2026."
  • Management expects the interworks.cloud acquisition to be "immediately accretive to our earnings and adjusted EBITDA."

Financial Results

  • Sullivan stated, "Gross billings increased 3% to $625.4 million... Net sales... increased 20% to $193.8 million... Gross profit in the fourth quarter was $29.8 million compared to $31.2 million."
  • SG&A expenses were $18.2 million, with SG&A as a percentage of gross billings at 2.9%.
  • Adjusted net income was $7 million or $1.53 per diluted share versus $10.3 million or $2.26 per share for the prior year.
  • Adjusted EBITDA was $13 million compared to $16.1 million for the same period in 2024. Effective margin was 43.6% versus 51.5% last year.
  • Cash and cash equivalents totaled $36.6 million, with working capital increasing by $27.7 million. Outstanding debt was $200,000 with no borrowings under the $50 million credit facility.

Q&A

  • Keith Housum, Northcoast Research, asked about year-over-year performance without last year's large transaction. Sullivan replied, "Our recurring and organic growth still was in the high teens for Q4 compared to Q4 of last year."
  • Housum inquired about the impact of the Citrix departure. Foster responded, "We looked at it as a $50 million to $60 million hole... our team still with that big hole, grew at 3%."
  • Housum questioned Interworks' EBITDA run rate. Foster said, "That's a good starting point for them... Microsoft... set a threshold. So there was a lot of scrambling... we get to that $30 million threshold with Microsoft."
  • Vincent Colicchio, Barrington Research, asked about broad-based growth and lumpy deals. Foster replied, "No lumpy deals in the quarter like we had before 2024 and Q4, but it was across our vendors." On AI, Foster indicated the company is identifying internal use cases and driving efficiency with its CIO.
  • William Dezellem, Tieton Capital Management, pressed for Fortinet relationship scale. Foster said, "It's about a $2.5 billion addressable market in the U.S... 10% of that is something that we're going after in the next 18 months, and we think we can get there. And I think Fortinet will be our top 3 vendor this time next year."
  • Howard Root, private investor, questioned M&A strategy and dividend suspension. Foster confirmed, "The dividend will be going toward the M&A side of things... I have... been in Western Europe more than I have been before because there's that many targets."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts focused on acquisition synergies, organic growth, vendor transitions, and profitability, showing constructive yet probing interest. The tone remained neutral to slightly positive, with congratulations on results and detailed questions on execution.
  • Management's remarks were confident and strategic, using phrases like "We expect the transaction to be immediately accretive" and "We are well positioned to deliver another year of growth." During Q&A, Foster remained candid yet optimistic, especially regarding M&A and operational efficiency.
  • Relative to the previous quarter, both management and analyst tone remain consistent, though the current quarter saw more emphasis on growth opportunities via M&A and vendor partnerships.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance language shifted to a stronger emphasis on M&A acceleration and capital reallocation, with the dividend suspension marking a notable change from prior quarters.
  • Strategic focus has intensified on vendor curation, onboarding larger partners like Fortinet, and expanding geographic reach through acquisitions such as interworks.cloud.
  • Key financial metrics show continued growth in billings and sales, while profitability measures, such as adjusted EBITDA and effective margin, declined due to the absence of large prior-year transactions.
  • Analysts maintained focus on organic growth, partner transitions, and the scale of new deals, with recurring questions about the durability of partnerships, vendor mix, and acquisition strategy.
  • Management’s confidence in operational improvements and efficiency measures has increased, with multiple references to leveraging AI and internal development for process acceleration.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management identified the risk of AI disruption in the market but expressed confidence in adapting quickly, stating, "We are still connecting technology builders with users. We can pivot quickly, as we have done over these last 8 years."
  • The departure of Citrix posed a revenue gap, but Foster emphasized successful vendor replacement and growth.
  • Working capital fluctuations were attributed to timing of collections and payables, with management expecting normalization.
  • Analyst concerns centered on sustained profitability, integration of acquisitions, and the scalability of new partnerships.
  • The decision to suspend the dividend introduces execution risk regarding capital deployment and the pace of M&A.

Final Takeaway

Climb Global Solutions' management highlighted a year of strong organic growth, strategic vendor partnerships, and a transformative acquisition in interworks.cloud. The company is reallocating capital from dividends to accelerate M&A and fuel expansion, with a clear target to capture $250 million in Fortinet-related gross billings within 18 months. Management remains confident in its adaptability, operational efficiency initiatives, and ability to replace lost vendor revenue, all while positioning Climb for continued growth and profitability in 2026.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Stellantis shares rise despite EV write-off as turnaround hopes build
data.description:
Despite suffering a sizable loss in 2026 tied to a €25B write-off on its electric vehicle business, shares of Stellantis (STLA) are higher on Thursday amid expectations that the company will return to a profit under the direction of CEO Antonio Filosa.

With the EV loss behind it, Stellantis (STLA) said it expects to “progressively” improve net revenue, adjusted operating income margin, and industrial free cash flow in 2026 and to see progressive improvements from the first half of the year to the second half.

“In the second half of the year we began to see initial, positive signs of progress with the early results of our drive to improve quality, strong execution of the launches of our new product wave, and a return to top-line growth. In 2026 our focus will be on continuing to close the execution gaps of the past, adding further momentum to our return to profitable growth,” Filosa said in a statement.

For FY25, however, the huge EV write-down drove Stellantis (STLA) to a loss of €22.3B ($26.3B) and an adjusted operating loss ((AOI)) of €842M with an AOI margin of negative 0.5%. This translated into a loss of €0.42 ($0.50) per share from a profit of €2.48 in 2024.

The write-off was reflected in the second half, where Stellantis (STLA) incurred a loss of €0.60 per share from a profit of €0.08 in H2 2024.

Sales improved, however, gaining 10% to €79.2B in the second half of 2025 from the same period last year, but were down 2% for all of 2025 to $153.5B.

Shipments in the second half of 2025 reached 2.8M units, up 11% year-over-year, with North America showing the strongest improvement of +39% from a year ago.

For the current year, Stellantis (STLA) expects to see a mid-single-digit percent increase in net revenue, a low-single-digit AOI margin (versus -0.5% in 2025)—albeit still pressured by a €1.6 tariff expense—and improved industrial free cash flow generation year-over-year (versus negative €4.65B in 2025).

data.title: Kansas City Fed Manufacturing Composite Index rises to 5 in February
data.description:
The Kansas City Composite Index came in at 5 in February, compared to 0 in January, according to data from the district Federal Reserve bank released on Thursday.

The Manufacturing Index stood at 10 in February, compared to -2 prior.

Developing... Check back for updates.

data.title: Qnity Electronics targets $100M EBITDA run rate improvement by 2028 through transformation plan
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Qnity Electronics, Inc. (Q) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Jon Kemp, CEO, opened the call by stating, "When we launched Qnity late last year, we detailed our focus on establishing ourselves as the premier technology solutions provider across the semiconductor value chain." He highlighted that Qnity delivered its seventh consecutive quarter of strong organic growth and exceeded full year 2025 financial objectives, growing organic sales by 10% and achieving an 11% increase in pro forma adjusted operating EBITDA year-over-year. Kemp emphasized the company's innovation in advanced nodes, advanced packaging, and the introduction of the Emblem CMP pad platform, which is designed for advanced chips and has received strong customer feedback. He also announced a multiyear transformation plan expected to deliver approximately $100 million EBITDA run rate benefit by the end of 2028.

  • Interim CFO Michael Goss reported, "We had a strong finish to the year with fourth quarter net sales of $1.2 billion, up 8% year-over-year." Goss shared that adjusted pro forma operating EBITDA was $349 million and adjusted pro forma EPS for the quarter was $0.82. He noted full year net sales of $4.75 billion, adjusted pro forma operating EBITDA of $1.4 billion, and an adjusted pro forma EPS of $3.35. Goss also announced a $500 million share repurchase authorization and described the company’s financial flexibility with a year-end total cash balance of over $900 million and net leverage of approximately 2.2x. He outlined the three areas of focus for the transformation plan: commercial and innovation excellence, productivity and quality improvements, and strengthening the local-for-local operating model.

Outlook

  • Qnity Electronics provided 2026 guidance with net sales expected in the range of $4.97 billion to $5.17 billion, adjusted operating EBITDA between $1.465 billion and $1.575 billion, adjusted EPS in the range of $3.55 to $3.95, and adjusted free cash flow of $450 million to $550 million. The company expects CapEx investment in 2026 to be 9% of sales, returning to a 6% run rate in future years. Kemp stated, "Our newly introduced full year 2026 guidance reflects our conviction that we can continue building on this momentum."

  • Management indicated that momentum from AI-led demand continues, particularly in the ICS segment, and expects high single-digit sequential net sales growth in the first quarter with a similar margin profile to Q4 2025.

Financial Results

  • Qnity reported fourth quarter net sales of $1.2 billion and adjusted pro forma operating EBITDA of $349 million. Adjusted pro forma EPS for the quarter was $0.82. The full year saw net sales of $4.75 billion and adjusted pro forma operating EBITDA of $1.4 billion, with a 29.5% margin. The ICS segment delivered net sales of $2.1 billion with 12% organic growth and over 25% EBITDA margin. Adjusted pro forma free cash flow for the year was $706 million, and the cash balance stood at over $900 million.

  • The company announced the Board’s approval of a $500 million share repurchase program and declared its first quarterly dividend.

Q&A

  • Bhavesh Lodaya, BMO Capital Markets: Asked about the EBITDA guide and key metrics like MSI and PCB. Kemp responded that MSI is expected to be mid-single digits, aligned with market indicators, and PCB trends are in the same range. Lodaya also asked about quarterly cadence, to which Goss replied, "We've seen less seasonality in our business...we do tend to see a peak -- a little bit of a peak in the third quarter."

  • John Ezekiel Roberts, Mizuho Securities: Inquired about the base tax rate and CMP use in packaging. Goss said the tax rate is expected to trend toward the high-teens over time. Kemp confirmed that CMP processes are used in advanced packaging and are a fast-growth area.

  • Christopher Parkinson, Wolfe Research: Asked about operating leverage in both segments. Kemp stated, "Within the semi segment, margins came in kind of in the mid-30s...really strong operating leverage within the ICS segment." Parkinson also questioned cash flow outlook; Goss attributed 2026's $500 million free cash flow guidance to elevated CapEx and ongoing transformation and IT projects.

  • James Schneider, Goldman Sachs: Asked about ICS growth and China sales. Kemp said ICS is expected to outperform semi, and China accounted for just over 30% of total sales, growing high single digits in 2025.

  • Arun Viswanathan, RBC: Asked about guidance range drivers and the transformation plan. Kemp tied low-end guidance to potential memory market constraints and high-end to customer capacity expansions. Goss noted the $100 million benefit from the transformation plan is expected to be realized by 2028, with early benefits in productivity and commercial excellence.

  • Additional questions covered ICS segment drivers, seasonality, growth rates in thermal management and packaging, and the degree of conservatism in the revenue guide. Kemp characterized the 2026 guidance as anchored around mid-single-digit market indicators plus expected outperformance.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts maintained a generally neutral to slightly positive tone, probing for clarity on guidance, growth drivers, and transformation execution. They pressed for details on seasonality, segment performance, and conservatism in the outlook.

  • Management presented a confident and optimistic tone in both prepared remarks and responses, using phrases like "we're proving that the next lead in AI...will be powered by materials innovation" and "we have strong confidence in the strength of our platform." The tone remained steady and constructive compared to the previous quarter, with increased emphasis on execution and transformation.

  • Compared to the previous quarter, both analysts and management continued to focus on operating leverage, segment growth, and macro recovery, with additional attention on execution of the transformation plan and capital allocation.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter introduced a multiyear transformation plan targeting $100 million EBITDA run rate improvement by 2028 and a $500 million share repurchase authorization, both new versus the prior quarter.

  • Guidance for 2026 reflects higher net sales and earnings targets, and management emphasized strong AI and advanced packaging demand as key growth drivers. The ICS segment remains a standout performer.

  • Analysts maintained focus on utilization trends, capacity investments, and segment growth. Management's confidence level increased, especially regarding transformation initiatives and capital deployment.

  • The prior quarter focused on the successful spin, initial public company momentum, and normalization following spin-related order timing. The current quarter shifts to operational execution, transformation, and capital allocation.

Risks and Concerns

  • Kemp acknowledged the "significant demand for AI and high-performance computing workloads is creating additional pressure on the global memory market" and noted that Qnity’s exposure is primarily to premium devices expected to be more resilient.

  • Management cited ongoing monitoring of memory market capacity concerns and recognized that "our exposure is largely driven to unit-driven consumables."

  • The company is watching for signs of downstream demand impact and is committed to supply security through strategic investments and local-for-local manufacturing.

  • Goss stated that elevated CapEx and transformation costs will impact free cash flow in 2026, with normalization expected in later years.

Final Takeaway

Qnity Electronics reported strong organic growth and margin performance for 2025, driven by continued strength in advanced nodes, packaging, and interconnect solutions, and introduced a transformation plan targeting $100 million EBITDA run rate improvement by 2028. Management remains confident in the company’s ability to outpace market growth in 2026, supported by robust demand for AI, high-performance computing, and advanced connectivity, while maintaining a disciplined approach to capital allocation and operational execution.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Cheniere Energy surges on big Q4 earnings beat, $9B boost to stock buyback authorization
data.description:
Cheniere Energy (LNG) +5.2% in early trading Thursday to its highest level in more than four months after crushing Q4 earnings estimates and raising its share repurchase target to more than $10B through 2030, reflecting a $9B increase to its existing authorization, which included $1B deployed in Q4.

Q4 attributable net income more than doubled to $2.3B, or $10.68/share, from $977M, or $4.33/share, in the year-earlier quarter, liquefied natural gas revenues jumped 24.5% Y/Y to $5.31B, and the number of cargoes exported increased ~11% to 185.

Q4 adjusted EBITDA jumped to $2.05B from $1.58B in the year-earlier quarter, beating the $1.95B analyst consensus estimate, primarily due to higher volumes of liquefied natural gas delivered, partially offset by lower total margins per MMBtu of LNG delivered; Q4 distributable cash flow of $1.49B topped the $1.32B consensus estimate.

Cheniere (LNG) introduced financial guidance ranges for FY 2026 of $6.75B-$7.25B consolidated adjusted EBITDA and $4.35B-$4.85B distributable cash flow, reflecting its previously announced LNG production forecast and expected completion this year of the remaining three trains at Corpus Christi Stage 3, which was 94.1% complete as of December 31.

The project is expected to add 10M metric tons/year of LNG to the company's production capacity of 15M tons/year at the Corpus Christi export facility.

Cheniere (LNG) said it shipped a record 670 cargoes in 2025, up 4% Y/Y.

Separately, Cheniere (LNG) said it entered into a long-term agreement to supply 1.2M metric tons/year of LNG to Taiwan's CPC during 2026-50.

Jefferies analysts reiterated their Buy rating and $251 price target on Cheniere (LNG) following the Q4 results.

data.title: Investors grow more cautious as bearish sentiment rises, shows latest AAII survey
data.description:
Market sentiment among individual investors grew more cautious in late February, according to the latest survey from the American Association of Individual Investors.

Bullish sentiment declined to 33.2% for the week ended February 25, down from 34.5% in the prior week, while bearish sentiment rose to 39.8% from 36.9%.

Equity markets were mixed during the week as investors assessed earnings developments and broader technology-sector trends, including results from Nvidia. U.S. indexes fluctuated, with technology shares experiencing periods of weakness even as some segments staged rebounds. Global markets showed a divided performance, with parts of Asia reaching record highs while European indexes softened after touching fresh peaks amid renewed tariff concerns.

Investors remained selective, with defensive positioning gaining traction at times. Bonds outperformed equities during periods of risk aversion, and gold attracted safe-haven demand.

Broader market commentary pointed to cautious trading conditions, uneven market breadth, and heightened sensitivity to policy, geopolitical, and technology-related developments.

According to AAII, neutral sentiment or expectations that stock prices will stay essentially unchanged over the next six months, edged down to 27.0% from 28.5% a week earlier.

The survey has been conducted by the American Association of Individual Investors since 1987, in which it asks respondents for their thoughts on where the market is heading in the next six months.

 

S&P 500 Tracking Funds: (MUTF:FXAIX), (MUTF:VFIAX), (MUTF:VFFSX), (MUTF:SWPPX), (NYSEARCA:SPY), (NYSEARCA:VOO), (NYSEARCA:IVV), (NYSEARCA:RSP), (NYSEARCA:SSO), (NYSEARCA:SH), (NYSEARCA:SDS), and (NYSEARCA:SPXU).

data.title: OpenAI plans London as largest research hub outside U.S.
data.description:
OpenAI (OPENAI) will launch its biggest research hub in London outside the United States, the company reportedly said on Thursday.

The company believes Britain’s technology ecosystem offers an ideal setting for investment and the development of new artificial intelligence systems, as per a Reuters report.

The country's blend of talent, leading universities, and globally respected scientific institutions gives it a competitive edge in a sector viewed as strategically important by governments worldwide, said Mark Chen, OpenAI's research chief.

Staff based at the new hub will “own key components” of its frontier AI model research, focusing on real-world applications and advancing the development of safe AI systems, the ChatGPT maker added.

However, specific details of the plan, like the size of any investment or the number of jobs it would involve, have not been made public.

OpenAI had opened its first international office in London in mid-2023. It currently has over 30 employees in its London team, according to Reuters.

data.title: Nasdaq drops nearly 2% as the tech selloff deepens post Nvidia's earnings
data.description:
Wall Street retreated on Thursday as weakness in the technology sector weighed heavily on major averages, pushing the Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) down nearly 2%.

The decline followed earnings from Nvidia (NVDA), with shares of the mega-cap chipmaker falling roughly 5% a day after reporting quarterly results. 

Semiconductor and semiconductor equipment stocks led the downturn, sliding about 5% on the session and dragging the broader information technology sector lower by approximately 2.5%. The pullback in chip-related names offset relative strength in other pockets of tech, including IT services, which climbed 4%. 

The uneven performance highlights the market’s heightened sensitivity to earnings from large-cap technology companies, particularly those tied to artificial intelligence and data center demand.

Outlined below are the Nasdaq-100’s (NDX) worst-performing stocks in Thursday’s trading session. 

  1. Applied Materials (AMAT), -6.8%
  2. Lam Research (LRCX), -6.7%
  3. Broadcom (AVGO), -6.6%
  4. Western Digital (WDC), -6.4%
  5. ASML Holding (ASML), -6.2%
  6. Seagate Technology (STX), -6.1%
  7. Micron Technology (MU), -5.9%
  8. Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR), -5.7%
  9. NVIDIA (NVDA), -4.9%
  10. Synopsys (SNPS), -4.7%

Nasdaq ETFs: (QQQ), (QQQM), (SQQQ), (TQQQ), (QLD), and (QID).

data.title: Warner Bros. Discovery targets over 140M streaming subscribers in Q1 2026 as global expansion accelerates
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) Q4 2025

Management View

  • David Zaslav, President, CEO & Director, stated that "Warner Bros. Motion Picture Group delivered a historic run of success with 9 films debuting #1 at the box office in 2025, 7 consecutive films opening with more than $40 million in box office sales, a first for any studio, and our films spent 16 total weeks atop the global box office." Zaslav highlighted the company's film slate success and the strong performance of original content and revived IPs, noting a significant awards season presence with 9 Golden Globe Awards and 30 Academy Award nominations.
  • Zaslav emphasized the growing strength of HBO and HBO Max, pointing to the debut of IT: Welcome to Derry as the "fourth strongest debut season in HBO history, averaging 27 million viewers per episode." He indicated momentum in streaming growth, surpassing the 130 million subscriber target, with a path to "more than 140 million total Streaming subscribers by the end of the first quarter" and a goal to "exceed 150 million subscribers by the end of the year."
  • Zaslav reported, "our portfolio of networks attracted 30% of all prime time cable viewing in the U.S., and we advanced critical initiatives like the launch of CNN All Access." He also cited a "sequential improvement in advertising trends during the fourth quarter, which has continued into Q1."
  • Zaslav described a strategic review and corporate reorganization, mentioning a "63% increase in value versus the first offer received in September" from the ongoing sales process, with the Board focused on maximizing value for shareholders.
  • Gunnar Wiedenfels, Senior EVP & CFO, stated, "Discovery Global would come out of the gate with roughly, call it, a 3.3x net leverage number. That is absolutely sustainable and supportable...we are very well able and willing to leverage the opportunities in our long-dated low interest capital structure."
  • Jean-Briac Perrette, President and CEO of Global Streaming & Games, outlined five levers for streaming growth: strengthened content, international volume and penetration growth (with password sharing enforcement ramping up in 2026), product enhancements, retention initiatives, and monetization through both pricing and ad sales expansion.

Outlook

  • Zaslav projected, "we are on track to reach more than 140 million total Streaming subscribers by the end of the first quarter. And we're well on our way to exceed 150 million subscribers by the end of the year."
  • Management described the 2027 film slate as "set to deliver a truly monumental year for Warner Bros." with major franchise releases, signaling ongoing investment in theatrical content.
  • Perrette stated, "we feel great about the next couple of years. And the really kind of sweet spot of the flywheel we're finally getting into to seeing content, marketing, product enhancements all flow together to drive that growth."
  • Wiedenfels said, "we're expecting to be flat to slightly up in international ad sales this year" and noted the capital structure post-spin as "absolutely sustainable and supportable."

Financial Results

  • Zaslav highlighted box office momentum with "Wuthering Heights, our ninth consecutive theatrical release to open #1, has generated over $160 million at the global box office in 2 weeks, including an $83 million opening weekend."
  • Wiedenfels referenced the Discovery Global spin-off, stating, "Discovery Global would come out of the gate with roughly, call it, a 3.3x net leverage number."
  • Perrette described streaming growth as "now exceeding the 130 million subscriber target we set out in August 2022."
  • Management noted "a sequential improvement in advertising trends during the fourth quarter, which has continued into Q1," and cited "more than 50% growth in linear hours viewed compared to the 2022 winter games" for the Milano Cortina Olympic Winter Games.

Q&A

  • Richard Greenfield, LightShed Partners, LLC: Asked about leverage at Discovery Global and why Versant is not a good comp. Wiedenfels responded that the capital structure is "absolutely sustainable and supportable" and does not see an issue with the leverage profile, emphasizing the company's scale and global opportunities.
  • Robert Fishman, MoffettNathanson LLC: Asked what is now being appreciated about the company's content and the growth drivers for streaming profits. Zaslav explained the focus on investing in original content, bringing back franchises, and a creative renaissance. Perrette detailed five levers for HBO Max growth, including content, international market expansion, product improvements, retention, and monetization.
  • Peter Supino, Wolfe Research, LLC: Inquired about international DTC expansion and ARPU. Perrette stated most markets have turned profitable within 1 to 2 years of launch, and the company's global IP reduces the need for extensive local content spending.
  • Bryan Kraft, Deutsche Bank: Asked about the games pipeline and network advertising. Perrette said 2025 was a reset year for games, with major launches coming in 2027-28. Wiedenfels described strong performance in advertising, noting "sequential improvement... after digesting 400 basis points of NBA headwinds" and strengths across key networks and international markets.
  • John Hodulik, UBS: Sought detail on ad and OpEx savings and sports business strategy. Wiedenfels pointed to "a big benefit from NBA cost savings" and ongoing efficiency focus, including the use of AI, with continued discipline in acquiring sports rights.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts were focused on leverage, international profitability, growth levers in streaming, and content investment, displaying a neutral to slightly positive tone, with some probing on risks and sustainability but not overt skepticism.
  • Management expressed confidence, describing the capital structure as "absolutely sustainable," and emphasized a "creative renaissance" and robust pipeline. The tone was confident and forward-looking, especially during remarks on streaming targets and content strategy.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management's tone remains confident and optimistic, with analysts continuing to probe on leverage and growth sustainability but showing less concern about execution risk given recent performance.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter emphasized the completion of a historic box office run and a record number of #1 debuts, whereas the previous quarter highlighted leadership in box office revenue and an ongoing transformation.
  • Guidance language shifted from building toward 150 million streaming subscribers by end of next year to being "on track" for 140 million by Q1 and exceeding 150 million by year-end.
  • Management continues to focus on global streaming expansion and franchise investment, with an increased emphasis on the Discovery Global spin-off and capital structure sustainability this quarter.
  • Analysts in both quarters concentrated on leverage, profitability, and international growth, with the current quarter Q&A reflecting more confidence in streaming profitability and the sustainability of the capital structure.

Risks and Concerns

  • Wiedenfels acknowledged investor focus on leverage for Discovery Global but described the capital structure as "absolutely sustainable and supportable."
  • The company noted ongoing "secular headwinds" for linear networks but cited improving advertising trends and audience delivery.
  • Management referenced the ongoing sales process and a rigorous, competitive environment, with a focus on maximizing shareholder value and mitigating downside risks.

Final Takeaway

Warner Bros. Discovery management highlighted a breakout year for original content and box office leadership, the surpassing of key streaming subscriber targets, and momentum in global expansion. The company projects ongoing growth in streaming and profitability, supported by an ambitious content slate, international market penetration, and disciplined capital management, while remaining focused on maximizing shareholder value and managing structural transitions, including the Discovery Global spin-off.
